com.samysadi.acs.core

Class Config

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.samysadi.acs.core.Config

  • public class Config
extends Object
    This class is used to keep different configuration values usually read from a configuration file.

    Configuration values are contexted. You can get an instance of Config containing only configuration values in a given context using addContext(String) method. Moreover, you can get the parent instance of a Config using parentContext().
    Note that contexted instances are transparently cached by this implementation. And modifications to any instance will reflect on the parent/children instances.

    There are multiple get and set method to access and modify configuration values (String, Boolean, Short, Integer, Long, Float, Double).
    These methods will only operate in the current context. Though, for get methods you can set a recursive flag in order to look for a configuration value in parent contexts when the configuration value is not present in current context.

    Configuration File Format:
    The configuration is a text file that contains a NAME=VALUE pair on each line.
    For each configuration file, we associate a load context that defines the default context of all the configuration values in that file. This default context can be modified using appropriate directives (see below). But all modifications will ensure that the new context is equal to or is a sub context of the file's load context.

    Configuration values are defined using a NAME=VALUE line.
    The NAME part of the line defines the configuration value name which may be split into one or more contexts. The VALUE part contains the string representation of the configuration value.
    For example:
    CloudProvider0.User0.Budget=500
    Tells that the configuration named "CloudProvider0.User0.Budget" has a value of 500. The dot (.) can be used to determine configuration contexts. You could use any of these next forms to access the previous configuration value:

    • config.getInt("CloudProvider0.User0.Budget");
    • config.addContext("CloudProvider0").getInt("User0.Budget");
    • config.addContext("CloudProvider0").addContext("User0").getInt("Budget");
    • config.addContext("CloudProvider0.User0").getInt("Budget").
    Note that some configuration names are reserved and are described below.

    Lines starting with a # are comment lines, and are ignored.

    Lines starting with context=, context=@ or context=% are special directives that defines the current context. All next configuration values are put under the given context.

    • context= computes the current context by appending the given context to the load context of the configuration file (which is empty by default);
    • context=@ computes the current context by appending the given context to the previous context of the configuration file;
    • context=% computes the current context by appending the given context to the parent context of the previous context of the configuration file.
    When using these directives, a $ can be used at the end of context name to ask the configuration file loader to replace it with a number that is automatically incremented starting from 0.

    Lines starting with include= are special directives that asks to include another configuration file.
    The load context of the configuration file is set to the current context.
    You can use relative paths when including the configuration file. The path is resolving using the current configuration file path as base path.

    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    Samy Sadi , Belabbas Yagoubi
